What is the purpose of the `refundfailedlaunch` command in Verus, and how does it work?

The `refundfailedlaunch` command in Verus is used to refund any funds sent to a chain if they are eligible for refund. This command attempts to refund all transactions for all contributors to the specified chain.

To use the `refundfailedlaunch` command, you need to provide the `currencyid` argument, which can be either an iaddress or a full chain name. This specifies the chain to refund contributions to.

The `refundfailedlaunch` command can be used in two ways: by running a command in the Verus executable or by making an API call using curl. Here are examples of both:

* Using the Verus executable: `verus refundfailedlaunch "currencyid"`
* Using curl to make an API call: `curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "refundfailedlaunch", "params": ["currencyid"] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/`

The `refundfailedlaunch` command is useful in cases where a chain launch has failed, and contributors need to get their funds back. By running this command, Verus attempts to refund all eligible transactions, ensuring that contributors can recover their funds.

refundfailedlaunch "currencyid"

Refunds any funds sent to the chain if they are eligible for refund.
This attempts to refund all transactions for all contributors.

Arguments
"currencyid"     (iaddress or full chain name, required)  the chain to refund contributions to

Result:

Examples:
> verus refundfailedlaunch "currencyid"
> curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "refundfailedlaunch", "params": ["currencyid"] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/
